articles.headline: Ecuadoreans Split on President’s Drastic New Measure to Combat Drug Gangs
articles.snippet: Vowing to bring peace back to a shattered country, President Daniel Noboa has deployed the military to take on what he calls “terrorist” groups.
articles.abstract: Vowing to bring peace back to a shattered country, President Daniel Noboa has deployed the military to take on what he calls “terrorist” groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: A sense of dread took hold in Ecuador on Wednesday, with the streets empty, schools closed and many people afraid to leave their homes after the disappearance of two gang leaders set off prison riots, police kidnappings and the on-air storming of a TV station.
articles.byline: By Annie Correal and Genevieve Glatsky

articles.headline: Regulators Approve New Type of Bitcoin Fund, in Boon for Crypto Industry
articles.snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission authorized financial firms to offer a Bitcoin investment product that some hope will accelerate adoption of the technology.
articles.abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission authorized financial firms to offer a Bitcoin investment product that some hope will accelerate adoption of the technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators on Wednesday approved a new financial product that tracks the price of Bitcoin, a landmark moment for the cryptocurrency industry that proponents hope will increase investment in the technology.

articles.headline: Trump’s Argument for Immunity in 2024 Is the Opposite of His Stance in 2021
articles.snippet: During his second impeachment trial, the former president argued that criminal prosecution was a more appropriate way to seek accountability since he had left office.
articles.abstract: During his second impeachment trial, the former president argued that criminal prosecution was a more appropriate way to seek accountability since he had left office.
articles.lead_paragraph: When former President Donald J. Trump appeared before an appeals court in Washington this week to claim he was immune from prosecution for his efforts to overturn the 2020 election, one of his lawyers argued that he should not face criminal charges because the Senate had failed to convict him of similar offenses at an impeachment trial three years ago.
articles.byline: By Alan Feuer and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Cockpit Recording’s Erasure Hampers Boeing 737 Max 9 Investigation
articles.snippet: Cockpit voice recorders in the U.S. start rerecording every two hours, a limit that the National Transportation Safety Board says should be extended to 25 hours.
articles.abstract: Cockpit voice recorders in the U.S. start rerecording every two hours, a limit that the National Transportation Safety Board says should be extended to 25 hours.
articles.lead_paragraph: Officials investigating why a panel on a Boeing 737 Max 9 blew open during an Alaska Airlines flight last week say they are struggling to piece together exactly what happened because the plane’s cockpit voice recorder overwrote itself before it could be retrieved.

articles.headline: Will Chatbots Teach Your Children?
articles.snippet: New A.I. tools could enable a Silicon Valley dream: bots that customize learning for pupils. Prior attempts have not lived up to the hype.
articles.abstract: New A.I. tools could enable a Silicon Valley dream: bots that customize learning for pupils. Prior attempts have not lived up to the hype.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sal Khan, the chief executive of Khan Academy, gave a rousing TED Talk last spring in which he predicted that A.I. chatbots would soon revolutionize education.

articles.headline: Fresh Inflation Data Shows Intact, but Bumpy, Cool-Down
articles.snippet: Inflation remains faster than usual — and month-to-month bumps are still likely as volatile prices fluctuate — but it is making progress back toward a normal pace.
articles.abstract: Inflation remains faster than usual — and month-to-month bumps are still likely as volatile prices fluctuate — but it is making progress back toward a normal pace.
articles.lead_paragraph: Consumer price data released Thursday showed Federal Reserve officials, the White House and American households that inflation continued to slow at the end of 2023, capping a year in which the price increases bedeviling families and policymakers cooled in earnest.

articles.headline: ‘Frozen Garlic!’ Taiwan Likes Its Democracy Loud and Proud
articles.snippet: At the island’s election rallies, warming up the crowd for candidates is crucial. “You have to light a fire in their hearts,” one host says.
articles.abstract: At the island’s election rallies, warming up the crowd for candidates is crucial. “You have to light a fire in their hearts,” one host says.
articles.lead_paragraph: Huang Chen-yu strode onto an outdoor stage in a southern Taiwanese county, whooping and hollering as she roused the crowd of 20,000 into a joyous frenzy — to welcome a succession of politicians in matching jackets.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley, Amy Chang Chien and Lam Yik Fei

articles.headline: Peacock Enters Uncharted Waters by Streaming N.F.L. Playoff Game
articles.snippet: The game, between the Kansas City Chiefs and Miami Dolphins, is the biggest test yet for whether live sports will find a comfortable home on streaming services.
articles.abstract: The game, between the Kansas City Chiefs and Miami Dolphins, is the biggest test yet for whether live sports will find a comfortable home on streaming services.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Saturday night, NBCUniversal will make media history. For the first time, a National Football League playoff game — this one featuring the Kansas City Chiefs and the Miami Dolphins — will appear exclusively on a streaming service.

articles.headline: As Utility Bills Rise, Low-Income Americans Struggle for Access to Clean Energy
articles.snippet: The Biden administration has deployed various programs to try to increase access to clean energy. But systems that could help lower bills are still out of reach for many low-income households.
articles.abstract: The Biden administration has deployed various programs to try to increase access to clean energy. But systems that could help lower bills are still out of reach for many low-income households.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cindy Camp is one of many Americans facing rising utility costs. Ms. Camp, who lives in Baltimore with three family members, said her gas and electric bills kept “going up and up” — reaching as high as $900 a month. Her family has tried to use less hot water by doing fewer loads of laundry, and she now eats more fast food to save on grocery bills.
articles.byline: By Madeleine Ngo and Ivan Penn
